content:
@Brock Whittaker @Tim Abbott @Rishi Gupta @Steve Howell @Greg Price
Dropbox with new design direction
https://dropbox.design/
Yeah, I saw that.
To be honest, I'm not impressed by what Dropbox is doing here.
At least, I can't tell how having the colors vary randomly improves anything :)

I would argue their design is definitely 'brave' (versus the other meaning of the word where it means 'removing the headphone jack'). Also they turned one of the most refined 'bluish-corporaty-not-that-brave' design to something 'art-ish' which is almost unprecedented for such a large company.
Considering that being different/distinctive is key, I would say I am fascinated.
I can't hardly see any difference in logged in UI. The changes appear to be ony in the logged out version. So I won't call it very brave :)
It's like no headphone jack when the phone is switched off :)
I'll be curious to see what they do with the logged-in site.
They're at least succeeding in getting a lot of attention
And if it's just a change to their landing pages, they can just change it back in 6 months and get some more PR.
I'll be curious to see what else they do with this direction.
Maybe I'm cynical, but all I saw was a new font, a new color scheme, and lots of buzzwords.

Kind of like Uber's old rebrand:
https://www.behance.net/gallery/43759199/Uber-Visual-Identity-Redesign
I think Uber's rebrand was a no-brainer, as it was a bit too tacky for a company of their size.

The best brand ever in the transportation business was Yellow Cab. They might have missed out on the whole Internet thing, but the Yellow Cab brand dominated for about a century.

"We have people driving around NYC. You hail them, and they take you to places. We calls these cars 'cabs.' And they're yellow."

:oncoming_taxi:

Dropbox used to be a lot less corporaty in its design than it's become in recent years -- like this shark-raptor-eagle version of the logo:
https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/1600/0*ExNQPgQM247gBne2.png

More here, from this past April:
https://medium.com/dropbox-design/illustrating-a-more-human-brand-part-1-e1cfe3c28d9
So this is a bit of a return to those days!

@Greg Price I totally remember these! They were a ton of fun!

  • startup phase 1: be cool
  • startup phase 2: be functional (corporate)
  • startup phase 3: be brave :wink:

Also :wave: I've not been on in a long time and I'm getting caught up with the hope to make some small usability and design contributions around stream management.
:wave: Hello @Sonali ! I liked the new guide to using streams (and Zulip generally) at RC that I saw go by recently, and would love to have some of that wisdom make it into our design and docs.
